title.narrative: F.a: Strengthening livelihood options of climate victims in semi-arid and forest regions of Tamil Nadu through adopting sustainable technologies

description.narrative: The project addresses the need to reduce the vulnerability of traditional communities of semi-arid and forest regions to climatic and environmental shocks, building their capacity so that they change existing patterns of natural resource dependence and are able to ensure effective utilization of natural resources through livelihoods diversification and sustainable technological interventions. ODAM has identified potential NGOs in the semi-arid regions of Tamil Nadu and formed network of local NGOs initiated for addressing climate change impacts through promoting sustainable and appropriate energy efficient technologies in the semi-arid region and farmers’ active participation in expanding the biochar related activities in their own field are the new streng ths of the project. The proposed action will network and advocate with several government organisations and institutions for policy support and for dissemination and extension of the successful models in other areas. Project objectives are: 1. To raise and address the climate crisis faced by traditional communities in semi-arid and forest regions through awareness generation on sustainable technologies; 2. To replicate the sustainable technologies that would reduce the carbon emission as well as to develop expertise and reduce the drudgery of the traditional communities to ensure their sustainable livelihood options; and 3. Networking with NGOs to promote energy efficient products for sustainable utilization of untapped/underutilized biomass in the forest an d semi-arid regions to initiate new avenues in their respective geographic areas. Target groups are: 1200 Small farmers, women, agriculture labourers and people involved in charcoal production in semi-arid regions of Tamil Nadu; 800 Adhivasis (tribal commu nities exclusively dependent on forest resources for subsistence) in the forest regions; 100 Nomadic tribes (Kurumba gounder); and 6 NGOs in semi-arid regions. ODAM, founded in 1995, is working with traditional communities in South Tamil Nadu, envisions se lf-reliant eco-villages to combat the negative impacts of globalization + climate change through revival of traditional practices with contemporary perspective towards enabling eco-friendly lifestyle and regeneration of the environment, and enabling state- of-the-art knowledge on appropriate sustainable technologies for enhancing quality of life of rural communities. www.odamindia.org
